title: Joint Reconstruction of Spatially-Coherent and Realistic Clothed Humans and Objects from a Single Image
author: Ayushi Dutta (University of Surrey), Marco Pesavento (University of Surrey), Marco Volino (University of Surrey), Adrian Hilton (University of Surrey), Armin Mustafa (University of Surrey), ...
background: The paper tackles the challenging problem of generating realistic 3D models of humans and objects from a single image, including addressing occlusions.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel framework for joint reconstruction of clothed humans and objects from single images, achieving superior spatial coherence and realism.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods primarily focus on either human or object reconstruction in isolation, which limits realism and detail.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines attention-based neural implicit modeling with a generative diffusion model to enhance reconstructive accuracy and detail retrieval.

key_innovation: Adapts attention mechanisms to merge features from input images and pose estimations, facilitating improved spatial coherence in the generated 3D shapes.
real_world_impact: The approach could significantly benefit applications in virtual reality, gaming, and film production by enabling the creation of realistic 3D avatars and environments.
limitations: The authors highlight the limitation of the method in explicitly modeling human-object interactions and handling cases where objects occlude humans.

new_terms.generative diffusion model: **Generative diffusion models** are a class of probabilistic models that gradually transform noise into data samples through a gradual denoising process.
new_terms.neural implicit model: **Neural implicit models** utilize deep learning to represent 3D objects as level sets of continuous functions, enabling fine-grained detail capture in reconstruction tasks.
